The Fort Qu'Appelle Vidoette last week quoted from The Progressor of Dec. 18, 1853, to endorse its point that "the power that be," and from our issue of the 16th of February last, to show that we have changed, and that we are not consistent. Our contemporary places extraordinary emphasis on our inconsistencies in the above dates, in column side by side, and palms them off as evidence of its assertion that we have been purchased to change its position. The distinguished members of the Vidoette are not to blame. It is welcome to all the comfort it can extract from the excerpts if has chosen to publish. Its editor must be looking through very distasteful spectacles when he sees any inaccuracy in the publications of others. But let us investigate them. The one taken from our issue of the 16th of February is part of an article in which we discussed the election returns of the Northwest Council, for their action on the Lieutenant-Governor's address, and in which we say that the every correctly represented the almost unanimous views of the people of the Territorial District. Such was the purpose of the extract which the Vidoette says is opposed to "the powers that be." The other excerpt, in which it proposes to see a change of tone, is a criticism of Mr. Jackson, who has attacked the members of the Northwest Council and his subsequent delivery of a speech at a banquet which was commonly described as "a most unbecoming hostility toward His Honour Lieutenant-Governor Dewdney. In the latter extract we condemn Mr. Jackson for attacking Mr. Dewdney under circumstances that precluded the possibility of a reply. Surely, the Vidoette would ask where is the inconsistency? Is it necessary to remind the editor of the Vidoette that Mr. Jackson does not constitute the whole membership of the Northwest Council, that he is but one man, and even then only a recently acknowledged leader? But while even the extracts which our contemporary quotes will not bear the extravagant interpretation placed upon them, we would ask where is the inconsistency? Is it necessary to remind the editor of the Vidoette that Mr. Jackson does not constitute the whole membership of the Northwest Council, that he is but one man, and even then only a recently acknowledged leader?

In the election for the Northwest Council in 1853, Mr. Jackson's opponent was Major Bell, one of the Hon. Mr. Justice. The whole campaign stock-in-trade was composed of bitter attacks on His Honour, Lieutenant-Governor Dewdney, and when he went to the very next session of the Council there was no difficulty in the election of Dewdney and nothing but the usual bitterness toward him. THE DAILY INTEREST

To THE EDITOR:

Sir,—With the development of agriculture in Manitoba, and the increase shown by the farmers of this province in their cattle raising, it becomes quite natural that we should follow the example of other provinces and our Dominion Government, in order to protect our interests as regards dairy farming, and form a dairy association for the purpose of obtaining better prices. I therefore invite correspondence from any brother dairyman on this subject, and would urge that the question be thought desirable, of holding a convention of the dairymen of the province at Winnipeg during the summer season of next year, to take steps as may be necessary to form an association such as I have mentioned, and of other matters of mutual interest.

WILLIAM WARDEN.

Commissioner for Woodlands.

**CORRESPONDENCE**

To the Editor:

Sir,—Can you find room in your valuable paper for a brief financial statement with regard to R. Peter's estate, Qu'Appelle? Enclosed is an itemized list of gifts given by kind friends in England and elsewhere, a sum close upon £200 having been paid by friends of Lord Granville, and I think the warmth of interest shown by them in their undertaking, and especially to those whose names appear, with Mr. John Milne's will, which bears a reproduction of Mr. Milne's own handwriting, should be appreciated.

The subscription list that was sent out included the names of all those who had made up their minds to pay for Mr. Milne's funeral expenses.

Enclosed also is a receipt with the full stamp, so that the late owner's bequest to the Church in honour of his name may be realized, the balance being transferred to the Presbyterian Church in Scotland.

I am heartily obliged,

[Signature]

P. R. Macmillan
